tn.text: Nahum continues describing the destruction of Nineveh in poetry that began in [[:en:bible:notes:nam:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Nineveh's soldiers killed many people. Alternate translation: "the city responsible for many people's deaths" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: heaps of corpses, great piles of bodies. There is no end to the bodies
tn.text: The author is stressing a great depth of slaughter against Nineveh since it was stated 3 times.
bodies of people who have died

tn.ref: There is no end to the bodies
tn.text: "There are a great many bodies"

As prostitutes sell physical pleasure and witches sell knowledge and power gained through magic, the people of Nineveh sell people they have taken in war and take profit from their sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This word serves to draw attention to what comes next.

tn.ref: who will weep for her?' Where can I find anyone to comfort you?
tn.text: Alternate translation: "no one will cry for her,' and I cannot find anyone to comfort her." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Nahum speaks to the people of Nineveh as though they were the city itself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])

tn.ref: are you better than Thebes ... itself?
tn.text: AT: "you are not better than Thebes ... itself." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
the former capital of Egypt, which the Assyrians had conquered

tn.ref: whose defense was the ocean, whose wall was the sea itself
tn.text: These two phrases share similar meanings. The words "ocean" and "sea" both refer to the Nile River which ran near the city and made attacking it difficult. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Ancient cities had a main "wall" to keep attackers out, and an outer line of "defense" to keep attackers from the wall.
Nahum speaks to the people of Nineveh as though they were the city itself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
This continues the comparison of Nineveh and Thebes from [[:en:bible:notes:nam:03:08|3:8-9]]. Possible meanings: "nevertheless" (UDB) or "even so"
the former capital of Egypt, which the Assyrians had conquered
Thebes.
The invaders killed the children of Thebes as easily as one breaks a clay pot. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
put into slavery. AT: "became slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Nahum speaks to the people of Nineveh as though they were the city itself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
This term, which could also be rendered as "strongholds" refers to all of Nineveh and the Assyrian empire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: All your fortresses will be like fig trees with the earliest ripe figs: if they are shaken, they fall into the mouth of the eater
tn.text: The city of Nineveh will be easy to take like fruit from a tree. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: the people among you are women
tn.text: "your people are weak and cannot defend themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
large beams of wood that give the gates strength and do not allow it to be opened from outside the city. Burning these would make it impossible to close the city again.
Nahum speaks to the people of Nineveh as though they were the city itself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])

tn.ref: It will devour you as young locusts devour everything
tn.text: It will destroy as locusts devour everything in their path. See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
the "fire" and "sword"

tn.ref: Make yourselves as many as the young locusts, as many as the full-grown locusts
tn.text: grown locusts** - "Multiply yourself like young locusts! Multiply yourself like adult locusts!" These words probably begin a new paragraph.

tn.ref: Make yourselves as many as the young locusts
tn.text: This means they would become a very large city with many people and destroy many lands. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Nahum speaks to the people of Nineveh as though they were the city itself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])

tn.ref: You have multiplied your merchants more than the stars in the heavens
tn.text: The merchants of Nineveh are as impossible to count as the stars in the sky. AT: "You have more merchants than anyone could count." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"traders" or "ones who buy and sell things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
Use a word for political "leaders" (UDB).
Use a word for military "leaders" or other government authorities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"Shepherds" here stands for the governors of the Assyrian people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Who has escaped your constant wickedness?
tn.text: AT: "Your constant wicked actions have hurt many people and nations." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
